these are galaxies and as astronomers we
have to deal with galaxies a lot um some
of them are beautiful swirly things
that's a technical term called spiral
galaxies and you can see lots of those
in these pictures and some of them are
Blobby round things not quite so
technical we call those elliptical
galaxies and this is a problem for us
because we used to have just a few
galaxies that we could see back in the
sort of 70s and 80s we would take a
picture of a galaxy a professor would
receive the picture and say I declare
this a spiral galaxy we shall study it
unfortunately robotics improved
telescopes improved and before too long
we were getting tens of thousands of
galaxies and in about 1996 or so we
built a thing that got us millions of
galaxies and in 2007 PhD student in
Oxford let's call him Kevin because
that's his name um he was told to look
through a database of galaxies here you
go Kevin here's a database I imagine
they handed him some kind of printed

but it was oldfashioned and they said
look through it and find us all this
very particular rare kind of galaxy and
so he said okay um because he's from
Switzerland he's very very organized he
was very good at this he's a professor
now by the way so he's wasn't harmed in
the making of this story um and so he
started looking through them and he
spent a week doing nothing but look
through galaxies exactly like these
saying whether they were elliptical or
spiral because a computer couldn't do
that for him and he needed to get it
done so at the end of the week he'd done
50,000 Galaxy
um and he was in a pub drinking heavily
and he said I can't really keep going
and I've only done 50,000 and there's a
million in the database and I found like
five of these weird galaxies what should
we do so him and some friends inspired
by things like seti at home and stardust
at home these kind of crowd sourcing
distributed computing projects that had
existed in 2000 2004 and such um this
was 2007 they made a website called
Galaxy zoo and Galaxy Zoo uh simply
showed people one of these galaxies and
asked them uh if it was spiral or
elliptical and this is the first 48
Hours of Galaxy Zoo's life um you've got
hours running along the bottom and
you've got classifications per hour up
on the side and so Kevin did 50,000
classifications in a week and you can
see that after two days we were doing
50,000 classifications an hour which is
a lot faster than Kevin um thankfully
and Kevin was pleased of course because
he didn't have to do it anymore um you
might notice on this graph though the
first seven hours were not exactly our
finest um we hosted this on a server at
Johns Hopkins University because that's
where the images already were uh we were
astronomers so we said oh it'll be fine
um and then we went on BBC breakfast and

which they went oh yeah we'll do that
we'll help you and everything broke and
so um thankfully a CIS admin at John's

otherwise we wouldn't be here today um
and got it running and you can pay your
way out of that problem right you you
can just get a bigger server and employ

it's much more sensible um to figure out
as we did about a year later that we
should just use this Cloud thing
everyone's talking about
we do all this for a great reason um not
just because we can do it fast and go on
BBC breakfast and things like that we do
it because we get lots and lots of
people to look at our data every single
Galaxy in that database was seen by
about 40 different people around the

elliptical isn't hard you don't need a
PhD in astronomy to do that and it seems
almost wasteful to make all the phds and
astronomy be the ones who do that and so
40 random people from around the world
can look at every Galaxy and they can
give us their opinion some of them will
say it's spiral some of them will say
it's elliptical and because of that we
get this statistical response to
everything in our database that's
brilliant we can get humans to do the
things computers can't do we can do it
at scale and we can do it very very fast
because people like science they like to
take part in it and do something
fun so Galaxy Zoo still exists um you
you can try it today although it will

400,000 people take part in this they've
done hundreds of millions of
classifications now we just keep finding
more galaxies to put through this engine
and what happened was Galaxy zoo was
rapidly joined by other websites other
people at the University and in other
universities came to us and said we want
to do a project too so before long we

all the time and the important thing for

and they
do so let me just show you three other
examples of projects uh that we have
just because this is fun and I have a
stage and a microphone so I might as
well uh old weather I will start with
old weather is a project where we get
people to look at handwritten Britain
ships logs from many many years ago and
in in the original case it was from the
Royal Navy around the time of the first
world war and these ship logs are
important because um not only do they
record the events that happened on board
every ship in the Royal Navy but all the
officers were told to six times a day
measure the air temperature sea
temperature the wind direction speed the
air pressure and all of that was done
with a calibrated and consistent set of
barometers and other instruments that
they were all trained to use in the same
way so as they sailed around the world
they mapped the climate of the world a
100 years ago and that's data that's
locked away in these handwritten records
which lovely though the handwriting is
escapes modern optical character
recognition so we got people to look
through this they went through a million
of these Pages for us and they mapped
the world's climate and these data go
into the Met Office climate simulations
that determine all sorts of things about
climate patterns and long-term changes
in the climate the reason people did
this though was nothing to do with
numbers I don't think it was because as
you're doing it you get to read all the
things that happen on the ship and so
we've got things here like leave for
boys until 1 pm until Mrs Smith has
finished with them I don't know who she
is um we've got a lecture by the
captain's subject the evolution of man
and then down at the bottom there 11:45
orders to commence hostilities against
Germany received not forgetting that
this all occurred during the first world
war one of the most interesting parts of
history and certainly in this part of
the world and so people are were quite
addicted to following these ships as
they sailed around the results um are
pretty incredible this is a map um of
the air pressure colorcoded Dots here uh
the colors for the air pressure roughly
paler the better the weather and these
are all individual log Pages flashing up
because for every log page you get a
latitude longitude all the details about
the we weather and the uh the war is
about to kick off so you'll see the The
Fleets come alive there we go and ships
cover the world they cover the oceans
the one place where we don't have
weather stations really um and this is
all predating satellite technology by a

whaling ships
records it's PR addictive watching that

these were given to us by the National

this is a map um of fatalities in

we can reconstruct major events and

human
beings we show people the pictures we

um you had to come up with something it

understandably wanted to know what the

and and in 2008 she asked what's this

and were connected together and
similarly those old weather logs books

this is HMS Africa um during

everyone on the ship out of a crew of
